awd_titl_txt: Nuclear, Particle, and Weak Interaction Physics of the Big Bang and Stellar Collapse
awd_abstract_narration:
This project probes the fundamental physics of neutrinos and nuclei by exploiting the intersection of exciting new developments in nuclear physics and neutrino physics on the one hand, and the increasingly sophisticated astrophysical and astronomical probes of compact objects, nucleosynthesis histories, and cosmology on the other. A key issue in this enterprise will be studying how neutrinos interact in dense matter and how these interactions may cause neutrinos to change their flavors. To these ends, this UCSD effort will work toward: (1) Formulating and understanding the quantum kinetic equations which govern neutrino flavor evolution in a general medium; (2) Constructing large-scale numerical simulations of neutrino flavor evolution in various supernova, stellar collapse, and compact object merger environments and assessing the feedback of this neutrino flavor physics on the prospects for the synthesis of nuclei in these sites; (3) Understanding neutrino-nucleus interactions, nuclear partition functions, and weak strength distributions in high temperature environments; and (4) Assessing how uncertainties and new beyond-standard-model possibilities in the neutrino sector could impact ideas on nucleosynthesis, dark matter, compact object physics, and cosmology, with an eye toward finding constraints otherwise unobtainable in the laboratory.

The research supported in this project will provide insights into how atomic nuclei and radiation behave in extreme conditions of temperature and density. In turn, these insights could give important clues about the nature of some elementary particles and the origin of the elements, for example, in the fiery interiors of supernova explosions, or at the time when the universe was only seconds old. These are fundamental questions that will provide unique opportunities for the training of young scientists, nuclear physicists, at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.

por.por_cntn:
My research project was focussed on fundamental nuclear physics and elementary particle physics, using sites in the cosmos effectively as "laboratories" to study this physics. This approach allows us to come at this science in ways complementary to, and sometimes quite different from, what we can learn in a laboratory. This research effort has facilitated the training of a number of young PhD nuclear physicists.

Quantum mechanics is humanity's theory for how nature works. Indeed, this physics is at the heart of almost all new technology, including emerging technologies like quantum computing. How information flows in quantum systems, especially how such systems lose their essentially quantum character, through a process we term de-coherence, remains a topic of importance. One key focus of the research in this project concerned quantum effects, including de-coherence, in the immense flux of neutrinos (elementary particles with no electric charge and tiny rest masses) accompanying the gravitational collapse of massive stars to form neutron stars and supernovae. Though neutrinos are notoriously "slippery", having very feeble interactions with matter, they nevertheless carry most of the energy in, e.g., core collapse supernovae and in the collisions of neutron stars (binary neutron star mergers). In a sense, they make up for their weak interactions with titanic numbers, e.g., roughly 10^58 neutrinos accompany the collapse of a massive star!

Just how these neutrinos carry and deposit energy in dense matter, and how they influence the nuclear composition of the ejecta from these cosmic events, depends on the "flavor" labels (electron, muon, or tau) that they carry, and the handedness (neutrino or antineutrino in one case) they posses. We know from recent experiments that neutrinos propagating in vacuum can change these labels. This research project used quantum mechanical calculations to model how neutrinos change flavors and handedness in the extremely dense environments associated with hot neutron stars, supernovae, and mergers. This is a vexing problem, in part because of the fiercely nonlinear nature of neutrino flavor transformation in environments with the huge numbers of neutrinos we expect in these cosmic venues: the flavors carried by the neutrinos in part determine how these particles change flavor! Moreover, neutrinos which scatter in this dense medium can lose quantum flavor coherence, also in a nonlinear fashion, further complicating the problem. This research effort formulated the basic equations which govern this complicated process, and solved them in interesting limits. The stakes are high, as the atomic nuclei (the elements!) created in these cosmic events may depend on neutrino flavor.

Indeed, a major thrust of the research in this project was directed toward understanding where the elements are made, and how these "nucleosynthesis" processes are tied into neutrino and weak interaction physics. One example concerns the site (or sites) of synthesis of the very heaviest nuclei, e.g., gold and uranium, in the so called rapid neutron capture process, r-process for short. The neutrino flavor transformation work in this project addresses one aspect of r-process nucleosynthesis in enviroments like supernovae and binary neutron star mergers where material is heated by neutrinos and ejected by neutrino interactions. Another, related issue addressed in this research project was the interaction of tiny primordial black holes with the dense matter in neutron stars. If these tiny holes comprise some of the dark matter, then this process can facilitate capture of these holes by neutron stars. If that happens, the neutron star is "eaten" by the hole, from the inside out, possibly spinning up the neutron star and thereby causing ejection of cold, neutron-rich material from the neutron star's surface. This ejected cold neutron matter could form an r-process.

The collapse of massive stars provides a "laboratory", albeit an exotic one, for studying the structure and behavior of nuclei in regimes of temperature and density difficult or impossible to mimmick in a terrestrial laboratory.  Another aspect of the research in this project revolved around very large numerical calculations of the structure and properties of the large, very highly excited nuclei that are important in stellar collapse. Understanding these properties, especially including how these nuclei are affected by weak interactions like electron and neutrino capture, help us to understand how core collapse supernovae work. Again, this could be important for understanding the origin of the elements.
